title: Jeremiah Chapter 11 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on Jeremiah chapter 11 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: Jeremiah Chapter 11 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of Jeremiah Chapter 11.

questions.question: Who received the word from the LORD in Jeremiah chapter 11?
options: Jeremiah
Moses
David
Elijah
questions.correctAnswer: Jeremiah
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 11:1 states that the word came to Jeremiah from the LORD.

questions.question: To whom was Jeremiah commanded to speak the words of the covenant?
options: The men of Judah and inhabitants of Jerusalem
The priests only
The kings of Israel
The prophets
questions.correctAnswer: The men of Judah and inhabitants of Jerusalem
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 11:2 commands Jeremiah to speak to the men of Judah and the inhabitants of Jerusalem.

questions.question: According to Jeremiah 11:3, what is said about the man who disobeys the words of the covenant?
options: Cursed be the man
Blessed be the man
He shall prosper
He shall be forgiven
questions.correctAnswer: Cursed be the man
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 11:3 states that cursed is the man who obeys not the words of this covenant.

questions.question: What did God command the fathers of Judah when he brought them out of Egypt?
options: Obey my voice and do all I command
Build altars to other gods
Ignore my commandments
Only observe the Sabbath
questions.correctAnswer: Obey my voice and do all I command
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 11:4 states God commanded obedience to His voice and all His commands when He brought their fathers out of Egypt.

questions.question: What did God promise to perform for the fathers of Judah?
options: The oath to give them a land flowing with milk and honey
To give them riches and gold
To make them kings over all nations
To grant them immortality
questions.correctAnswer: The oath to give them a land flowing with milk and honey
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 11:5 mentions God’s oath to give their fathers a land flowing with milk and honey.

questions.question: What did the LORD say Jeremiah must proclaim in the cities of Judah and streets of Jerusalem?
options: Hear ye the words of this covenant, and do them
Build new altars
Ignore the covenant
Pray to other gods
questions.correctAnswer: Hear ye the words of this covenant, and do them
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 11:6 commands Jeremiah to proclaim the words of the covenant and to do them.

questions.question: True or False: Jeremiah 11:7 states that God protested early and often to the fathers to obey His voice.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 11:7 says God protested from the day He brought them out of Egypt, rising early and protesting obedience.

questions.question: What did the people of Judah and Jerusalem do instead of obeying God's voice, according to Jeremiah 11:8?
options: Walked in the imagination of their evil heart
Kept the covenant faithfully
Built only the LORD’s altars
Went into exile immediately
questions.correctAnswer: Walked in the imagination of their evil heart
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 11:8 explains they did not obey but walked in the imagination of their evil heart.

questions.question: What was found among the men of Judah and inhabitants of Jerusalem, as revealed to Jeremiah?
options: A conspiracy
A festival
A covenant renewal
A peace treaty
questions.correctAnswer: A conspiracy
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 11:9 states a conspiracy was found among the men of Judah and inhabitants of Jerusalem.

questions.question: True or False: According to Jeremiah 11:10, the house of Israel and Judah kept the covenant God made with their fathers.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 11:10 says the house of Israel and Judah have broken God's covenant made with their fathers.

questions.question: What will happen to those who cry unto God in their trouble, according to Jeremiah 11:11?
options: God will not hear them
God will immediately save them
God will give them gold
God will send angels
questions.correctAnswer: God will not hear them
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 11:11 says though they cry to God, He will not hear them.

questions.question: Fill in the blank from Jeremiah 11:13: 'For according to the number of thy cities were thy gods, O ______;'
options: Judah
Israel
Jerusalem
Ephraim
questions.correctAnswer: Judah
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 11:13 says, 'For according to the number of thy cities were thy gods, O Judah.'

questions.question: What did the LORD say to Jeremiah about praying for the people in Jeremiah 11:14?
options: Do not pray for them for I will not hear
Pray earnestly for them
Pray only at the temple
Pray for their enemies only
questions.correctAnswer: Do not pray for them for I will not hear
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 11:14 states the LORD told Jeremiah not to pray for the people because He will not hear them when they cry for trouble.

questions.question: True or False: Jeremiah 11:16 describes Judah as a green olive tree fair and of goodly fruit before being broken.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 11:16 calls Judah a green olive tree, fair and of goodly fruit before the branches were broken.

questions.question: What punishment did God say He would bring upon the men of Anathoth in Jeremiah 11:22?
options: Young men shall die by the sword; sons and daughters by famine
They shall prosper and multiply
They will be taken captive but spared
They will receive riches and honor
questions.correctAnswer: Young men shall die by the sword; sons and daughters by famine
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 11:22 states God will punish the men of Anathoth with death by sword and famine for their sons and daughters.

medium.title: Jeremiah Chapter 11 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from Jeremiah Chapter 11 to real-life situations.

questions.question: How does Jeremiah 11 teach us about the importance of obedience to God's commands in everyday life?
options: Obedience brings blessings and establishes a faithful relationship with God
Obedience is optional and based on personal preference
Obedience only matters during church services
Obedience guarantees wealth and success
questions.correctAnswer: Obedience brings blessings and establishes a faithful relationship with God
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 11:3-5 emphasize that obeying God's covenant leads to being His people and receiving His promises, including the land flowing with milk and honey. The passage stresses the importance of following God's voice for a faithful relationship.

questions.question: A fellow believer is struggling to remain faithful amid temptations to follow other gods. Based on Jeremiah 11, what biblical truth would you share?
options: Turning away from God leads to inevitable judgment and trouble
God will ignore their prayers regardless of their actions
Following other gods is acceptable if it feels right
God blesses those who serve many gods
questions.correctAnswer: Turning away from God leads to inevitable judgment and trouble
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 11:10-13 warn that the house of Israel and Judah broke God's covenant by serving other gods, causing God to bring evil upon them. It teaches the seriousness of faithfulness and consequences of idolatry.

questions.question: How does Jeremiah 11 instruct believers about prayer and intercession for those who persist in disobedience?
options: Do not pray for those who refuse to repent because God will not hear them
Always pray for everyone without exception
Pray only after people change their behavior
Prayer is not necessary for others
questions.correctAnswer: Do not pray for those who refuse to repent because God will not hear them
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 11:14 instructs not to pray or cry out for the people because God will not hear them in their time of trouble due to their persistent disobedience and idolatry.

questions.question: What does Jeremiah 11 reveal about God's awareness and judgment of secret conspiracies against His prophets?
options: God knows all plots against His servants and will judge righteously
God is unaware of secret plans and cannot intervene
Conspiracies against prophets are justified
God ignores evil if it is done secretly
questions.correctAnswer: God knows all plots against His servants and will judge righteously
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 11:18-20 show that God gave Jeremiah knowledge of conspiracies against him and that God, who judges righteously, will execute vengeance on those who seek to harm His prophets.

questions.question: How does this chapter teach us about the consequences of ignoring God's covenant in family and community life?
options: Ignoring God's covenant leads to destruction and loss of blessing for families and communities
Breaking the covenant has no real consequences
Only individuals are affected, not families or communities
Consequences only come after many generations
questions.correctAnswer: Ignoring God's covenant leads to destruction and loss of blessing for families and communities
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 11:8-11 explains that ignoring God's covenant brings inevitable evil and punishment upon the people, affecting entire families and communities, including the men of Anathoth (Jeremiah 11:21-23).

questions.question: A believer is discouraged because of opposition at church. Based on Jeremiah 11, what encouragement can you offer about God's protection?
options: God sees all opposition and will bring righteous judgment in His time
Opposition means God has abandoned you
You should respond with anger to your opponents
Opposition is a sign of failure in faith
questions.correctAnswer: God sees all opposition and will bring righteous judgment in His time
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 11:20 shows Jeremiah’s prayer for God's righteous judgment against those who oppose him, assuring believers that God judges the heart and will act justly.

questions.question: What does Jeremiah 11 teach about the role of faithfulness in maintaining a healthy relationship with God?
options: Faithfulness to God's commands sustains His favor and presence
Faithfulness is unnecessary if you feel sincere
Faithfulness only matters during worship rituals
Faithfulness guarantees material wealth
questions.correctAnswer: Faithfulness to God's commands sustains His favor and presence
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 11:4-5 shows that obeying God's voice and keeping His covenant makes the people His own and secures His promises, highlighting the necessity of faithfulness for a blessed relationship with God.

questions.question: True or False: Jeremiah 11 teaches that God will always hear the prayers of those who persist in sin and idolatry.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 11:11 and 11:14 clearly state that God will not hear the cries of those who persist in sin and idolatry, emphasizing the need for repentance before prayers are heard.

questions.question: True or False: According to Jeremiah 11, God's covenant was originally given to the fathers when He brought them out of Egypt.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 11:4 confirms that God commanded the fathers at the time of the Exodus to obey His voice and keep the covenant, establishing the covenantal relationship.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: Jeremiah 11 describes the people of Judah as a _______ olive tree, fair and of goodly fruit, before God pronounced judgment upon them.
options: green
withered
barren
dead
questions.correctAnswer: green
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 11:16 describes Judah as a green olive tree, signifying its initial beauty and fruitfulness before God kindled fire upon it due to their disobedience.

questions.question: How does Jeremiah 11 instruct believers about the seriousness of idolatry in daily life?
options: Idolatry breaks God’s covenant and brings severe judgment
Idolatry is a minor offense with no lasting effect
Idolatry is acceptable if done secretly
Idolatry can be balanced with worshiping God
questions.correctAnswer: Idolatry breaks God’s covenant and brings severe judgment
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 11:10-13 highlights that turning to other gods breaks God’s covenant and leads to judgment, showing the gravity of idolatry in daily life.

questions.question: What practical spiritual discipline does Jeremiah 11 emphasize for the people of Judah?
options: Proclaiming and doing the words of God’s covenant
Ignoring God’s commands when convenient
Following the traditions of forefathers without question
Relying on the gods of the nations
questions.correctAnswer: Proclaiming and doing the words of God’s covenant
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 11:6 commands Jeremiah to proclaim the words of the covenant and urges the people to obey, stressing the discipline of hearing and doing God’s word.

questions.question: What warning does Jeremiah 11 give about the future of those who conspire against God's messengers?
options: They will be punished by death and famine with no remnant left
They will prosper and escape judgment
They will be forgiven without repentance
They will be exalted by the community
questions.correctAnswer: They will be punished by death and famine with no remnant left
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 11:21-23 prophesy that the men of Anathoth who seek Jeremiah’s life will face punishment by sword and famine, with no survivors, illustrating God’s judgment on conspirators.

questions.question: How does Jeremiah 11 encourage believers to respond to trials and opposition in their faith journey?
options: By trusting God’s righteous judgment and revealing their cause to Him
By taking revenge on opponents
By abandoning their faith to avoid trouble
By hiding their beliefs to stay safe
questions.correctAnswer: By trusting God’s righteous judgment and revealing their cause to Him
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 11:20 shows Jeremiah appealing to God as a righteous judge to see vengeance on his enemies, teaching believers to trust God with their cause amid trials.

questions.question: What does Jeremiah 11 teach us about the role of integrity and honesty in spiritual leadership and witness?
options: God reveals the plans of evil doers to His faithful servants so they can remain steadfast
Spiritual leaders should keep secrets to avoid conflict
Honesty is less important than popularity
Integrity is optional when facing opposition
questions.correctAnswer: God reveals the plans of evil doers to His faithful servants so they can remain steadfast
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 11:18 explains that God gave Jeremiah knowledge of conspiracies against him, underscoring the importance of integrity and God’s protection for faithful witnesses.

hard.title: Jeremiah Chapter 11 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from Jeremiah Chapter 11.

questions.question: What is the central command given by the LORD to Jeremiah in Jeremiah 11 concerning the covenant?
options: Speak to the men of Judah and Jerusalem to obey the covenant
Build new altars for Baal
Ignore the words of the covenant and prophesy peace
Lead a rebellion against the king
questions.correctAnswer: Speak to the men of Judah and Jerusalem to obey the covenant
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 11:2 instructs Jeremiah to speak to the men of Judah and inhabitants of Jerusalem to hear the words of the covenant.

questions.question: According to Jeremiah 11, what was the consequence for the man who did not obey the words of the covenant?
options: He would be cursed
He would be rewarded
He would be blessed with many children
He would become king
questions.correctAnswer: He would be cursed
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 11:3 states that the LORD says, 'Cursed be the man that obeyeth not the words of this covenant.'

questions.question: What historical event is referenced in Jeremiah 11 as the basis for the covenant God made with the fathers of Israel?
options: The exodus from Egypt
The conquest of Canaan
The Babylonian exile
The building of Solomon's temple
questions.correctAnswer: The exodus from Egypt
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 11:4 recalls God commanding the fathers in the day He brought them out of Egypt from the iron furnace.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: Jeremiah 11:5 mentions God’s oath to give the fathers a land flowing with ______ and honey.
options: milk
wine
oil
water
questions.correctAnswer: milk
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 11:5 explicitly states the land is flowing with milk and honey.

questions.question: What literary device is evident in Jeremiah 11:7-8 where God recounts rising early to protest and the people's disobedience?
options: Parallelism illustrating persistent divine warning
Chiasm contrasting obedience and disobedience
Typology foreshadowing the Messiah
Allegory representing the nations
questions.correctAnswer: Parallelism illustrating persistent divine warning
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 11:7-8 uses parallel structure to emphasize God's repeated warnings and the people's refusal to listen.

questions.question: Which phrase best describes the conspiracy mentioned by the LORD found among the men of Judah and Jerusalem?
options: Turning back to ancestral sins and idolatry
Plotting to overthrow the king
Seeking alliance with Egypt
Building new altars to the LORD
questions.correctAnswer: Turning back to ancestral sins and idolatry
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 11:9-10 details a conspiracy where the people revert to their forefathers' iniquities and serve other gods.

questions.question: True or False: According to Jeremiah 11, when the people cry out to God in trouble, He will hear and deliver them.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 11:11 states that although they will cry to the LORD, He will not listen to them.

questions.question: What is the significance of the altars set up in Jerusalem, as mentioned in Jeremiah 11:13?
options: They represent the multitude of gods Judah worshipped, including Baal
They were built for the LORD alone
They were symbolic of peace treaties with nations
They served as places for royal coronations
questions.correctAnswer: They represent the multitude of gods Judah worshipped, including Baal
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 11:13 describes numerous altars built to burn incense to Baal, symbolizing widespread idolatry.

questions.question: What reason does the LORD give in Jeremiah 11:14 for instructing Jeremiah not to pray for the people?
options: Because God will not hear their cry in the time of trouble
Because Jeremiah is to lead a rebellion
Because the people have repented fully
Because the temple is being rebuilt
questions.correctAnswer: Because God will not hear their cry in the time of trouble
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 11:14 explicitly tells Jeremiah not to pray for the people as God will not hear them when they cry out.

questions.question: In Jeremiah 11:16, the LORD calls Judah a 'green olive tree.' In biblical symbolism, what does this represent?
options: A nation once flourishing and fruitful
A tree of wickedness and sin
A symbol of exile and destruction
A foreign nation hostile to Israel
questions.correctAnswer: A nation once flourishing and fruitful
questions.explanation: The olive tree is often a symbol of prosperity and blessing; Jeremiah 11:16 calls Judah a green olive tree fair and fruitful.

questions.question: Which theme in Jeremiah 11 is foreshadowed by the 'fire' kindled upon the olive tree and broken branches?
options: Judgment and destruction due to Israel's sins
Restoration of the Davidic kingdom
The coming of the Messiah
The rebuilding of the temple
questions.correctAnswer: Judgment and destruction due to Israel's sins
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 11:16 uses the imagery of fire and broken branches as a metaphor for impending judgment on Israel.

questions.question: What is the significance of Jeremiah describing himself as a lamb or ox brought to slaughter in Jeremiah 11:19?
options: It symbolizes his innocence and the impending persecution he faces
It indicates he was a priest offering sacrifices
It means he was leading a rebellion
It reflects his role as a king
questions.correctAnswer: It symbolizes his innocence and the impending persecution he faces
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 11:19 uses the metaphor of a lamb or ox to show Jeremiah's vulnerable position and the plots against him.

questions.question: Jeremiah 11:20 shows a plea to the LORD of hosts who judges righteously. What does this reveal about Jeremiah's trust in God amid persecution?
options: Jeremiah appeals for divine justice against his enemies
Jeremiah doubts God's justice
Jeremiah plans to flee Jerusalem
Jeremiah asks for personal vengeance
questions.correctAnswer: Jeremiah appeals for divine justice against his enemies
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 11:20 presents Jeremiah asking God to enact vengeance because he has revealed his cause to God.

questions.question: Who are the men of Anathoth mentioned in Jeremiah 11:21-22, and what is their attitude toward Jeremiah?
options: They seek to kill Jeremiah for prophesying in the LORD's name
They support Jeremiah's message
They are foreign allies
They are priests urging peace
questions.correctAnswer: They seek to kill Jeremiah for prophesying in the LORD's name
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 11:21 describes men of Anathoth seeking Jeremiah's life, warning him not to prophesy or be killed.

questions.question: What punishment does the LORD declare against the men of Anathoth in Jeremiah 11:22-23?
options: Death by sword and famine with no remnant left
Exile to Babylon
Peace and restoration
Captivity in Egypt
questions.correctAnswer: Death by sword and famine with no remnant left
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 11:22-23 pronounces death by sword, famine, and no remnant for the men of Anathoth.

theological.title: Jeremiah Chapter 11 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from Jeremiah Chapter 11 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: What was the primary content of the covenant Jeremiah was commanded to proclaim to Judah and Jerusalem?
options: Obey the voice of the LORD and do all His commandments
Build altars and offer incense to Baal
Form alliances with foreign nations
Gather wealth and power for Jerusalem
questions.correctAnswer: Obey the voice of the LORD and do all His commandments
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 11:3-4 commands the people to obey God's voice and keep His covenant as given since the exodus. This is consistent with Deuteronomy 6:4-6, Exodus 19:5, John 14:15, and 1 John 2:3, which emphasize obedience to God's commandments as the mark of His covenant people.

questions.question: According to Jeremiah 11, what consequence is pronounced upon the man who does not obey the words of the covenant?
options: He shall be cursed
He shall become king
He shall be blessed abundantly
He shall be forgotten
questions.correctAnswer: He shall be cursed
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 11:3 clearly states that the man who disobeys the covenant is cursed. This aligns with Deuteronomy 28:15, Galatians 3:10, Hebrews 10:26-27, and Romans 1:18, which show that disobedience to God's covenant brings judgment and curse.

questions.question: What historical event is recalled as the basis for the covenant commands in Jeremiah 11?
options: The exodus from Egypt
The building of Solomon's temple
The destruction of Sodom and Gomorrah
The Babylonian captivity
questions.correctAnswer: The exodus from Egypt
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 11:4 refers to the day God brought the fathers out of Egypt as the time when the covenant was given. This is foundational in biblical theology, as seen in Exodus 20, Deuteronomy 5, Luke 24:27, and 1 Corinthians 10:1-4, emphasizing God's redemptive acts as the basis for covenant relationship.

questions.question: What did God promise to the fathers if they obeyed His voice and kept His commandments?
options: That they would be His people and He would be their God
That they would have no enemies
That they would live forever
That they would never suffer
questions.correctAnswer: That they would be His people and He would be their God
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 11:4 states that obedience would result in a special covenant relationship where God would be their God and they His people. This covenantal theme is central in Scripture, reflected in Exodus 6:7, Leviticus 26:12, 2 Corinthians 6:16, and Revelation 21:3.

questions.question: What is the nature of the land promised to the fathers according to Jeremiah 11:5?
options: A land flowing with milk and honey
A land of deserts and wilderness
A land of perpetual war
A land of ice and snow
questions.correctAnswer: A land flowing with milk and honey
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 11:5 recalls the promise of a fertile land flowing with milk and honey, symbolizing God's blessing and provision. This promise is foundational in the Old Testament (Exodus 3:8, Numbers 13:27, Deuteronomy 6:3) and is echoed in the New Testament as a symbol of God's abundant provision (Hebrews 11:9, Revelation 22:1-2).

questions.question: What did God say He would bring upon Judah and Jerusalem because of their disobedience to the covenant?
options: Evil that they cannot escape
Peace and prosperity
A new covenant of grace
Protection from enemies
questions.correctAnswer: Evil that they cannot escape
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 11:11 warns of unavoidable evil coming upon Judah and Jerusalem because they broke the covenant. This judgment motif is consistent with Deuteronomy 28:15-68, Ezekiel 14:12-23, Hebrews 10:26-31, and Romans 1:18-32, showing God's righteous response to persistent rebellion.

questions.question: What is the response of the people when they face trouble according to Jeremiah 11:12?
options: They cry unto their gods, but these gods do not save them
They repent and return to the LORD
They build new altars to the LORD
They flee to foreign lands
questions.correctAnswer: They cry unto their gods, but these gods do not save them
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 11:12 indicates that in trouble the people turn to their false gods, who fail to deliver. This reflects the futility of idolatry found throughout Scripture, as seen in Psalm 115:4-8, Isaiah 44:9-20, Habakkuk 2:18-20, and 1 Corinthians 8:4-6.

questions.question: According to Jeremiah 11, what is the significance of the 'altars to Baal' in Jerusalem?
options: They represent the people's idolatry and covenant unfaithfulness
They are places for genuine worship of the true God
They are monuments of past victories
They symbolize peace treaties with neighboring nations
questions.correctAnswer: They represent the people's idolatry and covenant unfaithfulness
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 11:13 speaks of altars to Baal as evidence of Judah’s spiritual adultery and rejection of the covenant. This theme is echoed in Judges 2:11-13, 1 Kings 18:21, Hosea 2:16-17, and Revelation 2:14, where idolatry is condemned as covenant betrayal.

questions.question: What instruction does God give Jeremiah regarding prayer for the people in Jeremiah 11:14?
options: Do not pray or cry for them, for God will not hear them
Pray fervently for their repentance
Lead them in prayer and fasting
Pray for their enemies as well
questions.correctAnswer: Do not pray or cry for them, for God will not hear them
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 11:14 commands Jeremiah not to intercede for the people because their persistent rebellion has rendered their prayers ineffective. This reflects God's judicial hardening, seen in Exodus 8:32, Romans 1:24-28, Isaiah 1:15, and Hebrews 10:26-31.

questions.question: How does Jeremiah describe the people of Judah in Jeremiah 11:15?
options: As one who commits lewdness and rejoices in evil
As a righteous and holy nation
As a humble and contrite people
As wise and understanding
questions.correctAnswer: As one who commits lewdness and rejoices in evil
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 11:15 portrays Judah as engaging in spiritual unfaithfulness and taking pleasure in evil deeds. This indictment parallels Hosea 4:12, Isaiah 1:4, Romans 1:32, and Ezekiel 16:49, which describe human sinfulness and rebellion against God.

questions.question: What metaphor does Jeremiah use in Jeremiah 11:16 to describe Judah before God's judgment?
options: A green olive tree, fair and of goodly fruit
A barren fig tree
A dry and withered vine
A mighty cedar in Lebanon
questions.correctAnswer: A green olive tree, fair and of goodly fruit
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 11:16 uses the metaphor of a flourishing olive tree to describe Judah’s original state. Olive trees symbolize blessing and covenant favor, as seen in Psalm 52:8, Romans 11:17-24, Romans 15:4, and Revelation 11:4, but the imagery also foreshadows judgment.

questions.question: What does God say has happened to the olive tree's branches in Jeremiah 11:16?
options: The branches have been broken due to a great tumult
The branches have grown stronger
The branches have been pruned for fruitfulness
The branches are untouched and flourishing
questions.correctAnswer: The branches have been broken due to a great tumult
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 11:16 describes how a tumult has kindled fire upon the olive tree, breaking its branches—symbolizing calamity and judgment on Judah. This imagery corresponds to Isaiah 10:33-34, Psalm 1:3-4, Ezekiel 15:2-6, and Hebrews 6:7-8, illustrating divine judgment on unfaithful covenant people.

questions.question: What knowledge did God give Jeremiah concerning the conspiracy against him, as stated in Jeremiah 11:18?
options: God revealed the doings of those plotting against Jeremiah
God told Jeremiah to flee the city immediately
God instructed Jeremiah to join the conspirators
God remained silent about the conspiracy
questions.correctAnswer: God revealed the doings of those plotting against Jeremiah
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 11:18 reveals that God gave Jeremiah insight into the conspiracies against him. This divine revelation and protection are consistent with Psalm 31:15, Isaiah 41:10, John 16:13, and Acts 9:15, where God informs and preserves His prophets.

questions.question: How does Jeremiah describe his own vulnerability in the face of the conspiracy against him in Jeremiah 11:19?
options: Like a lamb or an ox brought to the slaughter, unaware of the plot
Like a lion ready to roar and defend himself
Like a mighty warrior prepared for battle
Like a tree with deep roots unshaken
questions.correctAnswer: Like a lamb or an ox brought to the slaughter, unaware of the plot
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 11:19 portrays Jeremiah’s innocence and vulnerability, comparing himself to a lamb or ox unaware of the deadly devices against him. This reflects Christological themes of the suffering servant (Isaiah 53:7, John 1:29, 1 Peter 1:19, Hebrews 9:28).

questions.question: What is Jeremiah's prayer to the LORD concerning his enemies as recorded in Jeremiah 11:20?
options: Let me see your vengeance on them, for I have revealed my cause to You
Forgive them and restore their hearts
Hide me from their evil plans
Grant me riches and power over them
questions.correctAnswer: Let me see your vengeance on them, for I have revealed my cause to You
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 11:20 is a plea for divine justice against those conspiring against him, trusting God's righteous judgment. This aligns with Psalm 7:9, Romans 12:19, Revelation 6:10, and Hebrews 10:30, affirming God's role as just judge.
